channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2018 The New York Times Company

item.title: ‘Extreme’ Suffering in Syria as Government Steps Up Bombing
item.media:description: An injured man was rescued from a building that was hit in an airstrike on Tuesday in the rebel-held area of Eastern Ghouta on the outskirts of Damascus, Syria.
item.description: More than 80 people were killed in rebel-held areas amid carnage that the United Nations called “outrageous” and an international failure.
item.dc:creator: ANNE BARNARD

item.title: Taiwan Earthquake Toll Rises, With Many Missing
item.media:description: A building teetered Wednesday after its first floor collapsed in an earthquake in Hualien, in Taiwan’s east.
item.media:credit: Central News Agency, via Associated Press
item.description: At least six people were killed and dozens are believed to be trapped in buildings damaged by a magnitude-6.4 quake.
item.dc:creator: AUSTIN RAMZY

item.title: President Zuma’s Speech Postponed as South African Power Struggle Intensifies
item.media:description: Members of the African National Congress demonstrated in Johannesburg on Monday to call for President Jacob Zuma to resign.
item.description: With the president facing calls to resign, Parliament said the annual state of the nation address would be postponed, and the president met with the man who wants to replace him.
item.dc:creator: NORIMITSU ONISHI

item.title: Norovirus Sidelines Security Staff at Pyeongchang Olympics
item.media:description: South Korean soldiers replaced security guards at a checkpoint in Gangneung, South Korea, on Tuesday ahead of the opening of the Pyeongchang Olympic Games.
item.description: Dozens have fallen ill and at least 1,200 people are being tested for the highly contagious norovirus ahead of the start of the Winter Games.
item.dc:creator: MEGAN SPECIA and DONALD G. McNEIL Jr.

item.title: Poland’s ‘Death Camp’ Law Tears at Shared Bonds of Suffering With Jews
item.media:description: Prime Minister Mateusz Morawiecki of Poland at the Ulma Family Museum of Poles Saving Jews in World War II in Markowa, Poland, last week. He said a new law aimed to ensure the telling of “true history.”
item.media:credit: Maciek Nabrdalik for The New York Times
item.description: The president signed a law making it a crime to blame “the Polish nation” for the crimes of Nazi Germany. Scholars say it could whitewash history.
item.dc:creator: MARC SANTORA
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity

item.title: A Suffragette Milestone in U.K., but More to Do in Era of #MeToo
item.media:description: Life-size images of suffragists in Trafalgar Square on Tuesday, the 100th anniversary of women’s right to vote in Britain.
item.description: British women cited persistent problems with harassment and discrimination.
item.dc:creator: KIMIKO de FREYTAS-TAMURA

item.title: Melbourne Journal: A Wrestling Team in Australia Fights to Prove It’s Not an ‘African Gang’
item.media:description: South Sudanese immigrants at a beach in Melbourne, Australia. The government recently declared Victoria State had an “African gang” problem, but crime statistics do not bear out the claim.
item.media:credit: Matthew Abbott for The New York Times
item.description: The Sudanese community in Australia has come under unwelcome scrutiny after politicians said its members were behind a crime wave in Melbourne.
item.dc:creator: ADAM BAIDAWI

item.title: In Pakistan, Long-Suffering Pashtuns Find Their Voice
item.media:description: Demonstrators in Islamabad, Pakistan, last week. The police shooting of Naqeebullah Mehsud, an aspiring model, was “the tipping point” for ethnic Pashtuns angry about years of mistreatment by the state, a Pakistani newspaper editor said.
item.description: Thousands have protested for days in the capital, Islamabad, after a police killing brought years of anger and resentment to the surface.
item.dc:creator: MEHREEN ZAHRA-MALIK

item.title: As Trump Wavers on Libya, an ISIS Haven, Russia Presses On
item.media:description: The Libyan militia leader Gen. Khalifa Haftar, center, on Russia’s only aircraft carrier in January 2017.
item.description: In the absence of a coherent American policy for Libya, Russia is gaining influence in one of the most dangerous parts of the world.
item.dc:creator: JO BECKER and ERIC SCHMITT
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: For Korea Inc., Money and Politics Make an Awkward Olympics
item.media:description: A view of the Olympic Village this week as preparations for the Winter Games in Pyeongchang, South Korea, reached their final stages.
item.description: The Winter Games are heading to Pyeongchang at a time of reckoning about South Korea’s family-run business empires, some of which are Olympic sponsors.
item.dc:creator: RAYMOND ZHONG and PARK JEONG-EUN

item.title: Market Recovery Falters as Global Investors Grow Cautious
item.media:description: Shares in Japan were up about 1 percent at midday Wednesday, but they ended the trading day roughly where they’d begun.
item.description: Shares in Asia were flat or down late Wednesday, amid signs that Wall Street’s rebound from a sharp sell-off a day earlier may not last.
item.dc:creator: CARLOS TEJADA

item.title: Protesters in South Sudan Denounce U.S. Arms Embargo
item.description: Protesters outside the American Embassy in South Sudan accused the United States of supporting the rebels in the country’s civil war.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: SpaceX, North Korea, ‘Black Panther’: Your Tuesday Evening Briefing
item.description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
item.dc:creator: KAREN ZRAICK and SANDRA STEVENSON

item.title: Iran Returns Ailing U.S. Citizen to Prison in New Sign of Tension
item.media:description: Baquer Namazi
item.description: Baquer Namazi, 81, an American citizen and former Unicef diplomat, was ordered back to Tehran’s Evin Prison after a medical leave for heart problems.
item.dc:creator: RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: Scenes of Taiwan Quake Damage
item.description: Rescuers searched for survivors after a 6.4-magnitude earthquake struck Taiwan on Tuesday.

item.title: As Maldives Crisis Deepens, President Blames the Other Guys
item.media:description: President Abdulla Yameen of the Maldives, center, in Male, Maldives, on Saturday.
item.description: President Abdulla Yameen has cracked down on the opposition and the Supreme Court, but both sides are believed to be deeply corrupt. How did we get here?
item.dc:creator: JEFFREY GETTLEMAN and SUHASINI RAJ
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: Australia Diary: We Have to Get Naked
item.description: Visitors encounter a surprise on one of Sydney’s nude beaches.
item.dc:creator: DIANA OLIVA CAVE

item.title: Can Christian Louboutin Trademark Red Soles? An E.U. Court Says No
item.media:description: Christian Louboutin has registered a trademark in Belgium, the Netherlands and Luxembourg referring to “the color red (Pantone 18 1663TP) applied to the sole of a shoe.”
item.description: A legal adviser to the European Court of Justice has argued that the French shoe designer may not be entitled to trademark protection for his design signature.
item.dc:creator: ELIZABETH PATON

item.title: Kim Jong-un’s Influential Sister to Visit South Korea for Olympic Ceremony
item.media:description: Kim Yo-jong, the sister of Kim Jong-un, the North Korean leader, in Pyongyang last year. She will arrive in South Korea on Friday as part of North Korea’s 22-member government delegation to the Winter Games.
item.description: Kim Yo-jong will be the first immediate family member of North Korea’s ruling dynasty to set foot in South Korea.
item.dc:creator: CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: Success of Russia’s Female Figure Skaters Takes a Toll in Injuries and Stress
item.media:description: Evgenia Medvedeva competing at the European Figure Skating Championships in January in Moscow. She is widely expected to win a medal in women’s singles skating at the Winter Games.
item.description: The bodies of Russia’s young female skaters are breaking down as they push their performance in pursuit of gold medals and more difficult jumps.
item.dc:creator: JERÉ LONGMAN

item.title: Fake Doctor in India Suspected of Infecting Dozens With H.I.V.
item.description: He is thought to have reused the same dirty needle on dozens of poor patients, telling them an injection would make them feel better.
item.dc:creator: JEFFREY GETTLEMAN and HARI KUMAR

item.title: Taiwan Earthquake Kills at Least Four; Many Are Missing
item.description: The 6.4-magnitude quake struck at 11:50 p.m. near the city of Hualien. Some 145 people were unaccounted for.
item.dc:creator: AUSTIN RAMZY

item.title: Mercedes-Benz Quotes the Dalai Lama. China Notices. Apology Follows.
item.description: Daimler, the German company that owns the car brand, featured a quote on social media that is popularly attributed to the Tibetan Buddhist leader.
item.dc:creator: SUI-LEE WEE

item.title: U.K. Judge Upholds Julian Assange’s Arrest Warrant
item.media:description: Julian Assange on the balcony of the Ecuadorean Embassy in London in May. He took refuge there in 2012, and has been granted Ecuadorean citizenship.
item.description: Even if the charge had been dropped, the WikiLeaks founder may have remained in the Ecuadorean Embassy in London for fear of a secret U.S. extradition request.
item.dc:creator: CEYLAN YEGINSU

item.title: Poland’s President Supports Making Some Holocaust Statements a Crime
item.media:description: A rally outside the presidential palace in Warsaw on Monday, in support of a bill that would make it illegal to accuse the country of complicity in the Holocaust. A counter-protest also took place.
item.description: President Andrzej Duda said he would approve the law, but, in a concession to critics, he said the Constitutional Court would determine whether it violates freedom of speech.
item.dc:creator: MARC SANTORA
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity

item.title: Pence Doesn’t Rule Out Meeting North Koreans at Olympics
item.media:description: Vice President Mike Pence, center, at the Capitol for the State of the Union address last week. Mr. Pence is traveling to South Korea to attend the Olympics.
item.description: The vice president said “we’ll see what happens” when asked about the possibility of meeting with North Korean officials at the Winter Olympics in South Korea.
item.dc:creator: GERRY MULLANY

item.title: Hong Kong Court Throws Out Protest Leaders’ Prison Sentences
item.media:description: The pro-democracy activists Joshua Wong, Alex Chow and Nathan Law outside the Court of Final Appeal in Hong Kong on Tuesday.
item.description: The jailing of Joshua Wong and other protest leaders drew international scrutiny over accusations that the government was punishing political opponents.
item.dc:creator: AUSTIN RAMZY

item.title: Wall Street Halts a Global Rout
item.description: A day after markets fell more than 4 percent, Wall Street enjoyed a positive Tuesday as gains in consumer stocks helped stop a global sell-off.
item.dc:creator: MATT PHILLIPS

item.title: Workers of Germany, Unite: The New Siren Call of the Far Right
item.media:description: Guido Reil, a coal miner, in Bottrop, Germany. He was a longtime supporter of the center-left Social Democratic Party, but switched to the far-right Alternative for Germany party, or AfD, two years ago.
item.media:credit: Gordon Welters for The New York Times
item.description: Alternative for Germany, the first nationalist party to enter Parliament since World War II, is targeting working-class voters and labor unions that have supported the left for decades.
item.dc:creator: KATRIN BENNHOLD

item.title: Letter Suggests Pope Knew About Abuse Complaints, Despite Denials
item.media:description: Pope Francis in St. Peter’s Basilica at the Vatican last week.
item.description: Francis is said to have been given a letter in 2015 accusing a Chilean bishop of ignoring abuse. The pope has said he never heard about the claims.
item.dc:creator: ELISABETTA POVOLEDO

item.title: Italy’s Populists Turn Up the Heat as Anti-Migrant Anger Boils
item.media:description: Matteo Salvini, center, began his campaign before Italy’s election in March at a Roma camp in Via Germagnano, on the outskirts of Turin, last week.
item.description: Matteo Salvini has taken the Northern League national partly by stoking anti-immigrant fears. He could be the establishment’s next nightmare.
item.dc:creator: JASON HOROWITZ

item.title: Dow Jones, Donald Trump, Broadcom: Your Monday Evening Briefing
item.description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
item.dc:creator: ZACH JOHNK and SANDRA STEVENSON

item.title: Many Say He’s the Least Qualified Lawyer Ever to Lead a Guantánamo Case. He Agrees.
item.media:description: Navy Lt. Alaric Piette is the lone member of Abd al-Rahim al-Nashiri’s defense team after the other lawyers quit. Even Mr. Piette feels he is not qualified to try the case himself, but believes that leaving his client with no one would be worse.
item.media:credit: Lexey Swall for The New York Times
item.description: Lt. Alaric Piette knows he is unfit to be Abd al-Rahim al-Nashiri’s only lawyer. But leaving his client with no one, he says, would be worse.
item.dc:creator: DAVE PHILIPPS
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: From Oil to Solar: Saudi Arabia Plots a Shift to Renewables
item.media:description: Saudi Arabia’s biggest solar farm in operation covers a parking lot of the national oil company, Saudi Aramco.
item.media:credit: Christophe Viseux for The New York Times
item.description: Riyadh plans to build a $300 million solar farm that would generate enough electricity to power up to 200,000 homes, an example Saudi leaders hope will have positive consequences.
item.dc:creator: STANLEY REED

item.title: No Suspects in Killing of Eccentric American, a Kenyan Wildlife Expert
item.media:description: Esmond Bradley Martin, a wildlife advocate and expert on the illicit trade in ivory and rhino horn, speaking at the National Press Club in Washington in 2008. He was killed on Sunday at his home in Nairobi, Kenya.
item.description: Esmond Bradley Martin, an American in his 70s, was stabbed to death in his Nairobi home. Police officials and friends are searching for answers.
item.dc:creator: JEFFREY GETTLEMAN

item.title: Fact Check: Fact Check: Trump’s Criticism of U.K.’s National Health Service
item.media:description: Demonstrators calling for greater funding for Britain’s National Health Service in London this weekend.
item.description: President Trump said the British health service was “going broke,” and warned that Democrats want to pursue a similar model. Here’s a closer look at his claims.
item.dc:creator: CEYLAN YEGINSU

item.title: Videos of Syrian Militia Abusing Kurdish Fighter’s Corpse Stir Outrage
item.media:description: The family of Barin Kobani, a Kurdish fighter whose mutilated body was abused by Syrian rebels, at a mourning ceremony for her on Saturday.
item.description: “She’s beautiful, man,” a Syrian fighter says of the partly naked body in the video. The Free Syrian Army has ordered an investigation.
item.dc:creator: ROD NORDLAND
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: Kenya’s Government Returns Some TV Stations to the Air
item.media:description: A protest on Monday in Nairobi, Kenya, against the shutdown of major television channels.
item.description: The partial restoration came five days after a court order demanded an immediate end to the blackout. The censorship has stunned many in Kenya.
item.dc:creator: JINA MOORE

item.title: After Religious Clash in India, Rumors Create a False ‘Martyr’
item.media:description: Rahul Upadhyay, who was rumored to have been killed in clashes between Hindus and Muslims in India last month, is very much alive.
item.description: Rahul Upadhyay, 24, took to social media to declare, “I have not even received a scratch.”
item.dc:creator: SUHASINI RAJ and KAI SCHULTZ

item.title: Machete-Wielding Attacker Shot in Presidential Complex in Tehran
item.media:description: President Hassan Rouhani visiting the tomb of late Iranian supreme leader Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini in Tehran on Wednesday. He was away from the presidential complex during the attack on Monday.
item.media:credit: Presidential Office, via European Pressphoto Agency
item.description: The assailant, believed to be around 35, was dressed in a white shroud, symbolic in Shiite Islam of a willingness to die for one’s cause.
item.dc:creator: THOMAS ERDBRINK

item.title: Crisis Consumes a Land of Pretty Islands, as Justices and Ex-Leader Are Arrested
item.media:description: A protest on Sunday in Malé, the capital of the Maldives, against the government’s delay in releasing opposition leaders from jail, despite a Supreme Court order.
item.description: The U.S. has condemned the declaration of a state of emergency and other moves by the government.
item.dc:creator: HASSAN MOOSA and JEFFREY GETTLEMAN

item.title: Why Free a Serial Rapist? In the U.K., the Answer Is a Secret
item.media:description: John Worboys was convicted in 2009 of 19 offences linked to attacks on 12 women. But investigators, and later a High Court judge, said he had well over 100 victims.
item.description: The former London cabdriver John Worboys was jailed for 12 attacks on women, and has been linked to over 100. A decision to release him on parole has caused outrage.
item.dc:creator: RICHARD PÉREZ-PEÑA

item.title: Sole Surviving Suspect in Paris Attacks Stands Trial in Belgium
item.media:description: Security checks in Brussels on Monday before the opening of Salah Abdeslam’s trial.
item.description: Salah Abdeslam is accused of shooting at the police during a raid in Brussels as he fled capture after the 2015 attacks in France.
item.dc:creator: ALISSA J. RUBIN and MILAN SCHREUER
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: Hong Kong’s Courts Have Defended Its Freedoms. Is Beijing Changing That?
item.media:description: Hong Kong judges at a ceremony to mark the start of 2018. The common law traditions of the city’s judiciary date from the era of British colonial rule.
item.description: Since Hong Kong returned to Chinese rule, its British-created courts have protected the rule of law that made Hong Kong special. Now there are concerns of interference by Beijing.
item.dc:creator: AUSTIN RAMZY

item.title: China’s Trade Investigation Takes Aim at Trump’s Voter Base
item.media:description: A sorghum field in Plainview, Tex. The United States exported about 4.8 million tons of sorghum to China in 2017, worth about $1 billion, accounting for nearly all of China’s imports of the grain last year.
item.media:credit: Rodolfo Gonzalez/Austin American-Statesman, via Associated Press
item.description: Beijing’s move could lead to tariffs on U.S. sorghum and hurt the farmers who grow it, demonstrating how it might respond to tougher U.S. trade rules.
item.dc:creator: SUI-LEE WEE

item.title: In Costa Rica Election, Gay-Marriage Foe Takes First Round
item.media:description: Fabricio Alvarado in San José, Costa Rica. He won the first round of presidential voting on Sunday after campaigning against an international court’s demand that Costa Rica legalize same-sex marriage.
item.description: Fabricio Alvarado, an evangelical singer and ex-TV journalist, emerged to lead a crowded field by assailing a court ruling in favor of same-sex marriage.
item.dc:creator: ELISABETH MALKIN
item.category: Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships
